unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Pick a Card
question_text:
One card is to be picked from a deck of cards. A deck has $52$ cards, $2$ colors (red and black), $4$ suits (spades, clubs, hearts, diamonds), and $13$ different numbered cards including an ace, king, queen, and jack. Four of the following probability problems are done incorrectly. Which answer choice below is the one option that is done correctly?
Which answer choice below is the one option that is done correctly?

choices.text:
Find the probability of picking an ace or a red card.
p(ace or red card) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{26}{52}=\dfrac{30}{52}$

Find the probability of picking an ace or a jack.
p(ace or jack) $=\dfrac{4}{13}+ \dfrac{4}{13}=\dfrac{8}{13}$

Find the probability of picking an ace or a king.
p(ace or king) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{4}{52}=\dfrac{8}{52}$

Find the probability of picking a spade or a black card.
p(spade or black card) $=\dfrac{13}{52}+ \dfrac{26}{52}=\dfrac{39}{52}$

Find the probability of picking an ace or a heart.
p(ace or heart) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{13}{52}=\dfrac{17}{52}$

solution:
Solution

This problem can only be done with the adding of the two fractions if the items in the question are mutually exclusive. This means that the chance that they both occur is zero.

Mutually exclusive events can have their probabilities added. Since an ace and a king cannot be picked at the same time, they are mutually exclusive. Therefore, their probabilities can be added. Using a deck of cards with $52$ cards in it means that all of the denominators are $52$. (While fractions can be simplified, it is not done here.)

Since there are 13 different numbered cards, dividing 13 into 52 means that there are 4 of each numbered or type of card. Therefore, there are 4 aces and 4 kings, so that the chances of picking either one is:

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because an ace can also be a red card. This means that both events can occur, so that the events are not mutually exclusive and the probabilities cannot simply be added.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because, while this probability could be found, the wrong denominator is being used.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because a spade is a black card. This means that both events can occur, so that the events are not mutually exclusive and the probabilities cannot simply be added.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because an ace can also be a heart. This means that both events can occur, so that the events are not mutually exclusive and the probabilities cannot simply be added.
